subject: Re: Shavian - ad lib

messageBody:
Ð`Ð»Ð°Ð³Ð¾Ð´Ð°ÑÑ Ð²Ð°Ñ! I hope the Cyrillic shows up in
everyone's browsers.

I was not deterred however, since I take notes in Quikscript or Shavian
to speed up my own notetaking. It won't confuse anyone else.
As for incorporating some Shavian letters in the Quikscript alphabet,
didn't Read himself change several of his own Shavian letters into the
new alphabet he was inventing, while leaving others exactly as in
Shavian? Therefore, I saw no reason to defer my experiment.

And I'm doing very well, as my notes have speeded up noticeably!
Dankeschön!

Or, for non linguists, what I wrote in Russian at the beginning and
German at the end was simply, Thank you!



--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> cossyrosario scripsit:
>
> > Question: What do you think of the idea of using some Shavian
> > characters in QS, where one finds them more aesthetic or easier to
> > distinguish or easier to write like the Shavian version of Loll?
After
> > all, when speaking English we do take the liberty of using foreign
> > words, italicizing them, ad lib. Some Latin contractions are so well
> > known that we don't even recognize them as Latin, e.g., i.e. We
don't
> > even italicize these.
>
> We do not, however, use Cyrillic sha or Hebrew shin instead of the
> Latin "sh" combination (in English) or "sch" (in German) or "ch" (in
> French). Scripts are much more isolated from one another than
languages
> are. When we borrow a word from a language normally written in
another
> script, like Arabic "haboob", we romanize it first.
>
> --
> John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> Sir, I quite agree with you, but what are we two against so many?
> --George Bernard Shaw,
> to a man booing at the opening of _Arms and the Man_
>

languages

another
